017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ycwcm.ColorTools;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.BitConversion;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.MathTools;
022/**
023 * Various utility methods for working with colors encoded as packed floats in any of the formats this can use.
024 * <br>
025 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 12/2/2019.
026 */
027public class FloatColors {
028
029    /**
030     * Converts a packed float in HSLA format (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha) to a packed float in RGBA format.
031     * @param hsla an HSLA-format packed float
032     * @return an RGBA-format packed float
033     */
034    public static float hsl2rgb(final float hsla) {
035        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(hsla);
036        return hsl2rgb((decoded & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 24 & 0xFE) / 255f);
037    }
038
039    /**
040     * Converts the four HSLA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in RGBA format.
041     * @param h hue, from 0.0 to 1.0
042     * @param s saturation, from 0.0 to 1.0
043     * @param l lightness, from 0.0 to 1.0
044     * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
045     * @return an RGBA-format packed float
046     */
047    public static float hsl2rgb(final float h, final float s, final float l, final float a){
048        float x = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(h * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f), y = h + (2f / 3f), z = h + (1f / 3f);
049        y -= (int)y;
050        z -= (int)z;
051        y = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(y * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f);
052        z = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(z * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f);
053        float v = (l + s * Math.min(l, 1f - l));
054        float d = 2f * (1f - l / (v + 1e-10f));
055        v *= 255.999f;
056        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
057                (int)(v * MathTools.lerp(1f, x, d)) |
058                (int)(v * MathTools.lerp(1f, y, d)) << 8 |
059                (int)(v * MathTools.lerp(1f, z, d)) << 16 |
060                ((int)(a * 255.999f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
061    }
062
063    /**
064     * Converts a packed float in RGBA format to a packed float in "HSLA format" (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha),
065     * which isn't one of the regular formats this supports but can be useful for conversions.
066     * @param rgba an RGBA-format packed float
067     * @return an "HSLA-format" packed float
068     */
069    public static float rgb2hsl(final float rgba) {
070        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(rgba);
071        return rgb2hsl((decoded & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 24 & 0xFE) / 255f);
072    }
073
074    /**
075     * Converts the four RGBA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in "HSLA format" (hue,
076     * saturation, lightness, alpha), which isn't one of the regular formats this supports but can be useful for
077     * conversions.
078     * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0
079     * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0
080     * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0
081     * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
082     * @return an "HSLA-format" packed float
083     */
084    public static float rgb2hsl(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
085        float x, y, z, w;
086        if(g < b) {
087            x = b;
088            y = g;
089            z = -1f;
090            w = 2f / 3f;
091        }
092        else {
093            x = g;
094            y = b;
095            z = 0f;
096            w = -1f / 3f;
097        }
098        if(r < x) {
099            z = w;
100            w = r;
101        }
102        else {
103            w = x;
104            x = r;
105        }
106        float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
107        float l = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
108        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
109                (int)(255.999f * Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f))) |
110                        (int)(255.999f * (x - l) / (Math.min(l, 1f - l) + 1e-10f)) << 8 |
111                        (int)(255.999f * l) << 16 |
112                        ((int)(255.999f * a) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
113    }
114
115
116    /**
117     * Given a color stored as a packed float and an alpha multiplier to affect that color (between 0f and 1f, inclusive
118     * and clamped in that range), this makes a packed float color that has the same red, green, and blue channels but
119     * has its own alpha multiplied by {@code alpha}, without constructing any objects along the way. If you want to set
120     * the alpha without considering its current value, you can use {@link #setAlpha(float, float)}
121     *
122     * @param encodedColor a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
123     *                     or {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
124     * @param alpha  between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive, the alpha to multiply the color's own alpha by
125     * @return a color encoded as a packed float, using color's RGB channels but with its A channel times {@code alpha}
126     */
127    public static float multiplyAlpha(final float encodedColor, final float alpha) {
128        final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encodedColor);
129        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(bits & 0xFFFFFF
130                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) ((bits >>> 24) * alpha), 0), 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
131    }
132
133    /**
134     * Given a color stored as a packed float, and a desired alpha to set for that color (between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive
135     * and clamped in that range), this makes a new float that has the same red, green, and blue channels but has been
136     * set to the given alpha, without constructing any objects along the way. This does not consider the current alpha
137     * of the encoded color; if you want to do that, you can use {@link #multiplyAlpha(float, float)}.
138     *
139     * @param encodedColor a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
140     *                     or {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
141     * @param alpha        between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive, the alpha to set into the returned packed color
142     * @return another color encoded as a packed float, using encodedColor's RGB channels and the given alpha
143     */
144    public static float setAlpha(final float encodedColor, final float alpha) {
145        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encodedColor) & 0xFFFFFF
146                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (255f * alpha), 0), 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
147    }
148
149    /**
150     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
151     * as from {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} or
152     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be
153     * between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use end). Both start and end should use the same color space; that is, both
154     * could be produced using Oklab, both could be produced using IPT, or both could be libGDX-native RGB, but they
155     * can't mix. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
156     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
157     * @param end the target color as a packed float
158     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
159     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
160     */
161    public static float lerpFloatColors(final float start, final float end, float change) {
162        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(end),
163                ys = (s & 0xFF), cws = (s >>> 8) & 0xFF, cms = (s >>> 16) & 0xFF, as = s >>> 24 & 0xFE,
164                ye = (e & 0xFF), cwe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, cme = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
165        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (ys + change * (ye - ys)) & 0xFF)
166                | (((int) (cws + change * (cwe - cws)) & 0xFF) << 8)
167                | (((int) (cms + change * (cme - cms)) & 0xFF) << 16)
168                | (((int) (as + change * (ae - as)) & 0xFE) << 24));
169    }
170
171    /**
172     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change, but keeps the alpha of start and uses the
173     * alpha of end as an extra factor that can affect how much to change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
174     * as from {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt_hq.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)} or
175     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}, and change can
176     * be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use end). Both start and end should use the same color space; that is,
177     * both could be produced using IPT_HQ, or both could be produced using YCwCm, but not a mix of the two. This is a
178     * good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
179     * @param start the starting color as a packed float; alpha will be preserved
180     * @param end the target color as a packed float; alpha will not be used directly, and will instead be multiplied with change
181     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
182     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
183     */
184    public static float lerpFloatColorsBlended(final float start, final float end, float change) {
185        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(end),
186                ys = (s & 0xFF), cws = (s >>> 8) & 0xFF, cms = (s >>> 16) & 0xFF, as = s & 0xFE000000,
187                ye = (e & 0xFF), cwe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, cme = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF;
188        change *= (e >>> 25) * 0.007874016f;
189        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (ys + change * (ye - ys)) & 0xFF)
190                | (((int) (cws + change * (cwe - cws)) & 0xFF) << 8)
191                | (((int) (cms + change * (cme - cms)) & 0xFF) << 16)
192                | as);
193    }
194
195    /**
196     * Returns a 1:1 mix of color0 and color1. All colors should use the same color space.
197     * This is the same as calling {@link #lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} with a change of 0.5.
198     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
199     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
200     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
201     */
202    public static float mix(float color0, float color1) {
203        return lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f);
204    }
205
206    /**
207     * Returns a 1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, and color2. All colors should use the same color space.
208     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
209     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
210     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
211     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
212     */
213    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2) {
214        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f);
215    }
216
217    /**
218     * Returns a 1:1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, color2, and color3. All colors should use the same color space.
219     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
220     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
221     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
222     * @param color3 the fourth color to mix, as a packed float color
223     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
224     */
225    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2, float color3) {
226        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f), color3, 0.25f);
227    }
228
229    /**
230     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
231     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
232     * @param colors an array or varargs of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
233     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
234     */
235    public static float mix(float... colors) {
236        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0)
237            return 0f; // transparent, usually
238        float result = colors[0];
239        for (int i = 1; i < colors.length; i++) {
240            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / (i + 1f));
241        }
242        return result;
243    }
244
245    /**
246     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
247     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
248     * This is mostly useful in conjunction with {@link com.github.tommyettinger.ds.FloatList}, using its {@code items}
249     * for colors, typically 0 for offset, and its {@code size} for size.
250     * @param colors an array of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
251     * @param offset the index of the first item in {@code colors} to use
252     * @param size how many items from {@code colors} to use
253     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
254     */
255    public static float mix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
256        final int end = offset + size;
257        if(colors == null || colors.length < end || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
258            return 0f; // transparent, usually
259        float result = colors[offset];
260        for (int i = offset + 1, denom = 2; i < end; i++, denom++) {
261            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / denom);
262        }
263        return result;
264    }
265
266    /**
267     * Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array ofr varargs of alternating floats
268     * representing colors and weights, as with {@code color, weight, color, weight...}.
269     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
270     * @param colors an array or varargs that should contain alternating {@code color, weight, color, weight...} floats
271     * @return a mix of all colors given respecting their weights, as a packed float color
272     */
273    public static float unevenMix(float... colors) {
274        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0) return 0f;
275        if(colors.length <= 2) return colors[0];
276        return unevenMix(colors, 0, colors.length);
277    }
278
279    /**
280     * Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array of alternating floats representing
281     * colors and weights, as with {@code color, weight, color, weight...}, starting at {@code offset} in the array and
282     * continuing for {@code size} indices in the array. The {@code size} should be an even number 2 or greater,
283     * otherwise it will be reduced by 1. The weights can be any non-negative finite float values; this method handles
284     * normalizing them internally.
285     * @param colors starting at {@code offset}, this should contain alternating {@code color, weight, color, weight...} floats
286     * @param offset where to start reading from in {@code colors}
287     * @param size how many indices to read from {@code colors}; must be an even number
288     * @return the mixed color, as a packed float in the same color space as the given float colors
289     */
290    public static float unevenMix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
291        size &= -2;
292        final int end = offset + size;
293        if(colors == null || colors.length < end || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
294            return 0f; // transparent, usually
295        float result = colors[offset];
296        float current = colors[offset + 1], total = current;
297        for (int i = offset+3; i < end; i += 2) {
298            total += colors[i];
299        }
300        total = 1f / total;
301        current *= total;
302        for (int i = offset+3; i < end; i += 2) {
303            float mixColor = colors[i-1], weight = colors[i] * total;
304            result = lerpFloatColors(result, mixColor, weight / (current += weight));
305        }
306        return result;
307    }
308
309}
